headline: Manual pressure. Full control. Pocket-sized.
subheadline: The Viaggio's lever mechanism lets you control pressure ramp, peak, and decline by feel -- up to 9 bar, entirely in your hands. It's a manual profiling tool that weighs 1.2 kg.
hero_image_alt: Arco Viaggio portable espresso maker disassembled showing the precision lever mechanism and stainless steel basket, a hand grinder and precision scale beside it, a dark espresso shot in a clear glass showing syrupy body, workshop-style flat lay on a wooden surface
description_long: The Viaggio is deceptively capable. Yes, it's a travel espresso maker. But its lever mechanism gives you something most electronic machines don't: true manual pressure profiling. You control the ramp -- slowly build to pre-infusion pressure, hold, then push through to full extraction at up to 9 bar, modulating decline by easing off the lever. With a good hand grinder and a precision scale, you can produce shots that rival machines ten times its size. The fine-grind basket accepts standard espresso-grind coffee (no proprietary pods required), and the stainless steel construction means brew temperature retention is excellent when you preheat with hot water. For the barista who already has a main rig, the Viaggio is the analog companion -- a tool that sharpens your feel for pressure and extraction in a way that electronic machines can't teach.
use_case_headline: A pressure profiling tool for your hands.
use_case_body: Full manual control from 0 to 9 bar. Pre-infusion by feel. Declining pressure by easing the lever. The Viaggio teaches you things about extraction that a pump and a PID never will. Pair it with a hand grinder and a scale for a portable precision setup.

social_proof_quote.quote: I use the Viaggio as a training tool. Controlling pressure by hand has made me a better barista on my main machine -- I understand extraction profiles physically now, not just on a graph. And the shots are legitimately excellent with a good hand grinder.
social_proof_quote.name: Alex P.
